I came here with 2 of my girlfriends for SF Restaurant Week. We chose to do the 3-course menu and 2 wine pairings for $40. So worth it! We started with the focaccia bread. It was so soft, buttery, and had the perfect balance of salt and olive oil!! We were so impressed with the bread that we actually ordered 2 more refills on our plate.... Haha! I ordered the toasted farro and slow egg for my appetizer. I've never even had farro before (or knew what it was before googling) but it was actually very filling and yummy! The slow egg added creaminess and it also came with toasted bread and arugula. For entrees, I ordered the fried chicken with jalapeno buttermilk dressing and macaroni salad. The fried chicken was a huge portion and came with 3 boneless and skinless pieces of chicken! The chicken was juicy and had a fried outer coating that was perfectly seasoned! I also got to try the duck ravioli and that was good too. The sauce was slightly sweet and you can really taste the duck in it! For my last course, I ordered the butterscotch pudding. This was okay for me, and got a little too sweet. I liked the crunchy toffee pieces on top, but there were only a few. My friend ordered the key lime pie and that was awesome--tart and sweet at the same time. The crust was also noteworthy! As for the wine, i'm not much of a wine connoisseur so I can't say too much about that. Both the choices were good. My appetizer came with a pinot (I think), and and entree came with a rose. Blue Plate had really great service. We didn't even get dirty looks when ordering so much bread!! :D Hahaha. Our waitress was really friendly and made sure to let us know about Restaurant Week. I would consider coming here in the future because of the glorious mac and cheese reviews! Too bad it wasn't on the Restaurant Week menu.

A group of us came here to check out their menu during SF Restaurant Week recently. After looking over their offerings, i wasn't impressed so I decided to order off the regular menu. Blue Plate has a dimly lit, cozy feel, with rich brown wood colors everywhere. We had early reservations so they weren't as busy as I expected and I was able to appreciate the interior setting more than I normally would. I decided to go with the grilled squid as my starter and their well known Fried Chicken for my entree. The grilled squid was cooked in a chorizo aioli and it was decent. Tender and chewy. Their Fried Chicken with smoked jalapeno buttermilk dressing and with a side of macaroni salad was not entirely what I would have imagined. The breading was crispy and not thick but I thought the chicken could have been more juicy and tender. Not bad, but maybe my expectations were too high. Definitely good but not amazingly good. Our waitress was attentive and nice throughout our meal. It was easy in and easy out so no complaints with the service we received. I would have to say that Blue Plate is solid but I'm not running back anytime soon.

We had a really swell evening at Blue Plate. I don't usually care about the atmosphere of a restaurant (I know, I'm basically a caveman) but I think Blue Plate is a fantastic place to take a date. We sat in the back room with a view of the patio. Pretty quiet with an intimate feel, good lighting... oh, and the food is good too. Everyone talks about the fried chicken and mac & cheese here, but we were feeling a little healthier so we passed on the two most popular items. Also we knew we wanted ice cream after, heheh. Surprisingly, the highlight of the meal for me was the grilled kale salad. I know, what?? You can get a kale salad wherever... but this one was pretty special. Varying textures thanks to those pecan "breadcrumbs", thinly sliced apples, and you could really taste the grill flavor on that kale salad. Very well done, and so worth ordering! The rest: Focaccia: Very tasty, but a little greasy. Still good. Brussels: Yuuuum. Loved the sweetness of the sauce, balanced with the feta and perfectly cooked sprouts. Mushrooms: Definitely very smoky. I'm not a big smoke fan, but my friend loved these. Could have used a little bit of acid for me. Gnocchi: This one was a bit of a miss for me. At first, I kept remarking how much this dish tasted like plants, but later all I could taste was the cod. They omitted the sausage from the dish for us, and my friend thought that may have thrown off the balance a little bit. Maybe. But the flavor of the cod was odd for me. The gnocchi texture was perfect though, so you know I ate the whole thing anyway :) Beets: This was a gift from the kitchen, and MAN these were great! Salty from the pastrami curing, with nice texture combination from the crunchy leeks on top... heavenly. Great flavor combos here, and everything was enjoyable in its own way. I really enjoyed Blue Plate and I'd gladly come back when I'm feeling gluttonous to try the mac and chicken!

Alas, I have returned for the fried chicken. Alas, it is just as wonderful as I remembered. Blue Plate participates in SF Restaurant week, and we scored a prime-time reservation on Friday night for their $40 pre-fix menu. 1. Pre-fix is a steal. I order the lamb spam (I would recommend), fried chicken (again, recommended), and key lime pie (highly, highly recommended). My partner ordered the beet salad (pretty darn good), crab ravioli (GET THIS), and coconut cream pie (not half bad). 2. Mac and cheese is good, but I remember it being GREAT. Sadly, the affects of alcohol kids. 3. Like most SF restaurants, the tables are very close together and you can hear everyone's conversation. Kind of awkward? Also kind of fun for people watching? Try to score the booth next to the window in the front. 4. I try to limit myself on the bread intake (try is the key word), and their rosemary focaccia is incredible. Like. I googled how to make it when I got home, though unfortunately no results. 5. Bernal heights.... kind of a trek for me, but hey you can go to the Royal cuckoo or El Rio after! Would I come back? Probably to get the pie, yes. And the bread.

We came here one night for a nice dinner out. It was only a few blocks from our old place and I will say, it's a hidden gem. The restaurant is pretty tiny so make sure to make a reservation. Food: For an appetizer, we got the burrata with walnut toast. This was very delightful and not too heavy. Great app. My boyfriend got the rabbit ravioli and me, the friend chicken with macaroni salad with jalapeno buttermilk dressing. My boyfriend was extremely satisfied with his entrée as well as me. The portion was a good size that I even got to take home leftovers for the following day's lunch. For a side we got the macaroni and drunken Spanish goat cheese. I am a sucker for mac-n-cheese and, boy, this did not disappoint! As much as the appetizer, entrees and sides were delicious, the most memorable part of the dinner was dessert. We got the butterscotch pudding. Now, you may think, butterscotch pudding? Like Swissmiss? No! This was by far the most delicious pudding I've ever had. It came with some brittle which made every bite scrumptious. It was smooth, crunchy and just to die for. Ambience: Like I said previously, this place is small but there is also a back room and courtyard. We were seated at a table by the window overlooking the courtyard, it was picture perfect (hence the picture I've posted ) The night we dined it was chilly. However, people still braved the outdoors and the service gave out comfy looking blankets. Service: Our server was very, how can I explain, very --San Francisco. He was very chill but quirky. Anytime he came over to our table, he made us smile for one thing or another. I was a bit concerned in the beginning since he seemed TOO chill but his service wasn't compromised. This place is cool because I think they have a somewhat revolving menu. Would DEFINITELY recommend!! So good!

Blue Plate - you are now on my radar. I am surprised more people do not talk about Blue Plate. We came here for SF Restaurant Week. I picked Blue Plate because it was the only place that had a rezzy during the time we wanted and in an area where parking would not be horrendous (for a friend meeting up with us). I came to catch up with some old friends and had low expectations for the food because....well....I have never heard anyone talk about Blue Plate. This was a good thing because I was still recovering from a cold, so I did not have an appetite - good or bad food was not important. Even sick, the food was pretty dang good. I had the beets as my appetizer, crab ravioli for my main and the key lime pie for dessert. The bread they gave was so good too, that you really have to force yourself to not get full off the bread alone. I was pretty impressed with everything the table ordered and everyone in the party agreed that we would come back. Great atmosphere, great service and great food. I need to come back when I am healthy and have a full appetite because that fried chicken looked SO GOOD!!!!

Total hipster place for sure. As agreed by my boyfriend and myself. So we came here for my birthday last week. Blue Plate happen to be in my bookmarks, but I almost forgot why I had bookmarked it?? Then I looked at the pictures, and I think bookmarked it because I remember that my bf likes deviled eggs and the ones pictured seemed delish along with a few other dishes plus its high ratings. The place has a cozy, hipster, rustic look to it. It was an open kitchen which was cool. There was this weird painting on the wall which seemed like bulls/cows with a human & an odd creature. Idk.. =/ I think they change their menu from time to time cause there were pictures of dishes that weren't on the current menu. There were like a total of 20 words on the menu that we had no idea what it means at all. We ended up getting the deviled eggs, fried chicken, and meatloaf. All were okay tasting. Bf ordered the Underberg (?) after the meal to see if it can help digestion. No idea that it was an alcoholic mini bottle which smelled like licorice (ew). The one thing I really liked about this place was the milk bottle for the water. I kept on adoring it so much throughout our dinner that boyfriend ask our server if we can purchase it. Got it for $2! Hahaha yay :)

On the outside, Blue Plate looks like it could only fit 20 people or less. However when walking inside the restaurant, you see a bigger dining hall in the back. The atmosphere is fun, lively, and grand. Our server chatted with us in a casual manner and recommended some great dishes we had for the evening. Main dishes aside, one of my favorite things here was the focaccia bread. It was flavorful and had just the right amount of salt. I made sure to ask the server for extras. Regarding the starters, we had a grilled octopus dish. The grilled essence of the octopus mad the dish feel hearty and satisfying. This is a dish worth getting. In addition, out group tried the fried chicken and the pork shoulder. The fried chicken was tender and the outside was crisp. However, it felt really heavy and after 1 piece of chicken, I was already full. The pork shoulder was another good dish, with a fig spread that's taste reminisced of evenings in front of a wood fireplace. However, the pork was a bit chewy at some parts. I would recommend getting the chicken over the pork. Desert was great part of our meal, but its not necessarily worth the price. The key lime pie was good, but not outstanding and the same goes for the butterscotch pudding.

We had a great evening at the Blue Plate sitting at the bar watching the cooks. The selection of small plates is great, everything tastes new and different and we liked the wine selection. My favorite was the butternut scotch pudding. Simply awesome. We'll be there again soon.

On the coldest night of the year, Blue Plate failed to warm me. We were seated in the back and the staff kept opening the door to the patio for some reason. Every time that door was open, we got a blast of cold air. The soup I ordered was served lukewarm. The scallops were downright cold - the bowl, the pasta, the sauce, and the scallops themselves were all ice cold. The menu didn't say it was served chilled. I can only guess that it sat on a counter waiting for the other dishes for my table to be prepared. $28 for three scallops. I also had the mac and cheese (warm but not hot) and one taste was enough. $10. Dining companions were not all that impressed with the meatloaf. The chocolate "cake" was an unappetizing brown blob. The key lime pie was excellent, but by then it was too late to save the meal. The place was too loud. Our waiter, Z, was AWOL shortly after we were seated. It took entirely too long for him to take our dinner order. When he finally did, I had to raise my voice so he could hear me. Here's a tip - if you can't hear a customer, walk over to the side of the table where the customer is seated. Don't make me shout across the table because the restaurant where you work has made no effort to control the noise level. RESTAURANT 101 - HOT FOOD SHOULD BE SERVED *HOT* And turn the music off. It just adds to the noise level.

    I came here with 2 of my girlfriends for SF Restaurant Week. We chose to do the 3-course menu and 2 wine pairings for $40. So worth it!

    We started with the focaccia bread. It was so soft, buttery, and had the perfect balance of salt and olive oil!! We were so impressed with the bread that we actually ordered 2 more refills on our plate.... Haha!

    I ordered the toasted farro and slow egg for my appetizer. I've never even had farro before (or knew what it was before googling) but it was actually very filling and yummy! The slow egg added creaminess and it also came with toasted bread and arugula.

    For entrees, I ordered the fried chicken with jalapeno buttermilk dressing and macaroni salad. The fried chicken was a huge portion and came with 3 boneless and skinless pieces of chicken! The chicken was juicy and had a fried outer coating that was perfectly seasoned! I also got to try the duck ravioli and that was good too. The sauce was slightly sweet and you can really taste the duck in it!

    For my last course, I ordered the butterscotch pudding. This was okay for me, and got a little too sweet. I liked the crunchy toffee pieces on top, but there were only a few. My friend ordered the key lime pie and that was awesome--tart and sweet at the same time. The crust was also noteworthy!

    As for the wine, i'm not much of a wine connoisseur so I can't say too much about that. Both the choices were good. My appetizer came with a pinot (I think), and and entree came with a rose.

    Blue Plate had really great service. We didn't even get dirty looks when ordering so much bread!! :D Hahaha. Our waitress was really friendly and made sure to let us know about Restaurant Week. I would consider coming here in the future because of the glorious mac and cheese reviews! Too bad it wasn't on the Restaurant Week menu.

    A group of us came here to check out their menu during SF Restaurant Week recently. After looking over their offerings, i wasn't impressed so I decided to order off the regular menu. Blue Plate has a dimly lit, cozy feel, with rich brown wood colors everywhere.
    We had early reservations so they weren't as busy as I expected and I was able to appreciate the interior setting more than I normally would.

    I decided to go with the grilled squid as my starter and their well known Fried Chicken for my entree. The grilled squid was cooked in a chorizo aioli and it was decent. Tender and chewy. Their Fried Chicken with smoked jalapeno buttermilk dressing and with a side of macaroni salad was not entirely what I would have imagined. The breading was crispy and not thick but I thought the chicken could have been more juicy and tender. Not bad, but maybe my expectations were too high. Definitely good but not amazingly good.

    Our waitress was attentive and nice throughout our meal. It was easy in and easy out so no complaints with the service we received. I would have to say that Blue Plate is solid but I'm not running back anytime soon.

    Blue Plate - you are now on my radar. I am surprised more people do not talk about Blue Plate.

    We came here for SF Restaurant Week. I picked Blue Plate because it was the only place that had a rezzy during the time we wanted and in an area where parking would not be horrendous (for a friend meeting up with us). I came to catch up with some old friends and had low expectations for the food because....well....I have never heard anyone talk about Blue Plate. This was a good thing because I was still recovering from a cold, so I did not have an appetite - good or bad food was not important.

    Even sick, the food was pretty dang good. I had the beets as my appetizer, crab ravioli for my main and the key lime pie for dessert. The bread they gave was so good too, that you really have to force yourself to not get full off the bread alone. I was pretty impressed with everything the table ordered and everyone in the party agreed that we would come back. Great atmosphere, great service and great food.

    I need to come back when I am healthy and have a full appetite because that fried chicken looked SO GOOD!!!!

    12/5/2015

    5 photos

    On the outside, Blue Plate looks like it could only fit 20 people or less. However when walking inside the restaurant, you see a bigger dining hall in the back. The atmosphere is fun, lively, and grand. Our server chatted with us in a casual manner and recommended some great dishes we had for the evening.

    Main dishes aside, one of my favorite things here was the focaccia bread. It was flavorful and had just the right amount of salt. I made sure to ask the server for extras. Regarding the starters, we had a grilled octopus dish. The grilled essence of the octopus mad the dish feel hearty and satisfying. This is a dish worth getting.

    In addition, out group tried the fried chicken and the pork shoulder. The fried chicken was tender and the outside was crisp. However, it felt really heavy and after 1 piece of chicken, I was already full. The pork shoulder was another good dish, with a fig spread that's taste reminisced of evenings in front of a wood fireplace. However, the pork was a bit chewy at some parts. I would recommend getting the chicken over the pork.

    Desert was great part of our meal, but its not necessarily worth the price. The key lime pie was good, but not outstanding and the same goes for the butterscotch pudding.

    According to their overall 4-star rating, life-altering comfort food can be had at Blue Plate; I unfortunately failed to unearth the menu's buried treasure on my visit.

    I craned my neck to get a visual & a whiff of what was coming out of the open kitchen -- my way of assessing popular & delicious options since I was a newbie. Neither meatloaf nor fried chicken looked appealing, both drab & sad-looking. In the end, I chose a vegetarian option: artichoke risotto. If you think my choice inane, his tri tip disappointed just as bad.

    Sides of brussel sprouts & goat cheese mac & cheese (no room to try the latter) were heavily salted. Butterscotch pudding had so much smokiness, I swear someone dropped a cigarette butt in the mix.

    This meal makes me think I was right to stay away all these years. Be it carb or meat, side or dessert, we can't find an item worth complimenting.

    2/19/2018

    On the coldest night of the year, Blue Plate failed to warm me.  We were seated in the back and the staff kept opening the door to the patio for some reason.  Every time that door was open, we got a blast of cold air.

    The soup I ordered was served lukewarm.  The scallops were downright cold - the bowl, the pasta, the sauce, and the scallops themselves were all ice cold.  The menu didn't say it was served chilled.  I can only guess that it sat on a counter waiting for the other dishes for my table to be prepared.  $28 for three scallops.  

    I also had the mac and cheese (warm but not hot) and one taste was enough.  $10.

    Dining companions were not all that impressed with the meatloaf.  

    The chocolate "cake" was an unappetizing brown blob.  The key lime pie was excellent, but by then it was too late to save the meal.

    The place was too loud.  Our waiter, Z, was AWOL shortly after we were seated.  It took entirely too long for him to take our dinner order.  When he finally did, I had to raise my voice so he could hear me.  Here's a tip - if you can't hear a customer, walk over to the side of the table where the customer is seated.  Don't make me shout across the table because the restaurant where you work has made no effort to control the noise level.

    RESTAURANT 101 - HOT FOOD SHOULD BE SERVED *HOT*

    And turn the music off.  It just adds to the noise level.
